title: Scafell Pike Walk - Easiest Route Route

images.title: John Dyason / Scafell from Scafell Pike
images.caption: Scafell from Scafell Pike. The "ridge" of Mickledore in centre frame, crossing to Broad Stand. As you climb, the lower slopes are characterised by grasslands and heather moorland, featuring species like bilberry, crowberry, and native grasses. These areas also host small mammals such as voles and red squirrels. Further up, the conditions become harsher, with scree slopes and rocky outcrops supporting resilient plants like mosses, lichens, and the rare Alpine Clubmoss, which thrive in these high-altitude, nutrient-poor environments.

images.title: Steve Partridge / Memorial Cairn on Scafell Pike.
images.caption: Memorial Cairn on Scafell Pike. A few feet from the trig point and built in memory of the men of the Lakes who lost their lives in WW I.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Cairn amongst a boulderfield on Scafell Pike. Cairns are essential to beable to follow the path on an otherwise featureless landscape.Birdlife is a highlight on this route, with ravens and peregrine falcons commonly seen soaring above. The elusive ring ouzel, often called the "mountain blackbird," can sometimes be spotted. On calmer days, deer may be glimpsed on the lower slopes, particularly red deer. In addition, streams and small tarns along the route occasionally support aquatic life such as trout.

images.title: Michael Graham / Trig Pillar, Scafell Pike
images.caption: Trig Pillar. Spring appears to have come early to Scafell Pike with daffodils growing out of the trig pillar. Looking north over Great Gable on one of the best fellwalking days of the winter.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Boulder strewn channel of Lingmell Gill

images.title: Nigel Chadwick / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Wasdale Head Inn Hotel, Wasdale Head. A fine place for refreshments after your exercise.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Large Cairn by the path down from Scafell Pike. Note Mickledore in the distance.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Large boulder by the path down from the Pike, with the valley of Lingmell Gill behind.

description: Climb the highest mountain in England on this spectacular walk in the Lake District. Scafell pike stands at a height of 978 metres (3,209 ft) between Eskdale and Wasdale, at the northern end of Wast Water. The route below is the shortest, most direct way to the summit. Although still very challenging it is probably the easiest route up to Scafell Pike. It starts from the car park at Lake Head Car Park, Wasdale and heads east to Lingmell Gill, Lingmell Scars and Hollow Stones before finishing at the highest point where you will find an Ordnance Survey triangulation column beside a huge cairn. The views are stunning with the coast, the Isle of Man and Snowdonia all visible on a clear day. For a different, more scenic route to the summit you can try the Scafell Pike from Borrowdale route. This longer route takes you around Styhead Tarn and along the famous Corridor Route. The Scafell Pike from Langdale route is another popular route. It is a longer and more challenging climb, but with some wonderful views of the Langdale Valley and a visit to Angle Tarn. Another great climb also starts from Wasdale Head. The circular climb to Pillar is a splendid walk taking you to the eighth highest point in the Lake District.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Head to the Wasdale Head Inn for some well earned post walk refreshments. Described as the the birthplace of climbing the inn has an interesting history stretching back over 200 years. They do very good food and have a decent selection of ales too. It's located close to the car park at postcode CA20 1EX for your sat navs. The inn is also dog friendly and will provide water bowls for your thirsty friend.

display_address: Lake Head Car Park, Old Corpse Road, Wasdale, Cumberland, England, CA20 1EX, United Kingdom
